Knowledge Point: The most frequent postpositions in Ulwa are listed in \REF{ex:otherwc:1}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:otherwc:2} through \REF{ex:otherwc:21} illustrate various use of these postpositions. When an NP ends in (or consists entirely of) an \isi{object marker}, this \isi{object marker} \isi{clitic}izes to the following \isi{postposition}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Mala} ay mankap. | \gll ma=\textbf{ala} ay ma=nïkï-p | \gls 3SG.OBJ=for sago 3SG.OBJ=dig-PFV | \glt `[They] made sago for him.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ata ma mïka \textbf{ndawat} namana. | \gll ata ma mïka anda=\textbf{wat} na-ma-na | \gls up go tree.species SG.DIST=atop DETR-go-IRR | \glt `[He] will go up, go onto that tree.’

Knowledge Point: Postpositions may be followed by the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be at’ (or its \isi{suppletive} \isi{past} form wap ‘be.\textsc{pst}’) to encode predicative spatial meaning. When \isi{spatial postposition}s can convey either stationary or \isi{direction}al meaning (e.g., in ‘in, into’), generally only the static sense is felt (e.g., in p- ‘is in’), as in examples \REF{ex:otherwc:22} through \REF{ex:otherwc:27}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yawat mï Sinda \textbf{kanam pe} ame. | \gll Yawat mï Sinda \textbf{kanam} \textbf{p-e} ama-e | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ [name] beside be-DEP eat-IPFV | \glt `The spear is next to the tree.’
Content 2: \gsrc Inom ndï umbe nungol \textbf{ndul pïna}. | \gll inom ndï umbe nungol ndï=\textbf{ul} \textbf{p-na} | \gls mother 3PL tomorrow child 3PL=with be-IRR | \glt `The mothers will be with the children tomorrow.’

Knowledge Point: These \isi{verb phrase}s \isi{head}ed by \isi{locative verb}s and containing \isi{postpositional phrase}s can further take the \isi{nominalizing} \isi{suffix} -en ‘\textsc{nmlz}’ (\sectref{sec:3.2}), as in \REF{ex:otherwc:28} and \REF{ex:otherwc:29}.
Content 1: \gsrc ngunan ato inkaw \textbf{ngawat pen} ngala | \gll ngunan=n ata-u inkaw nga=\textbf{wat} \textbf{p-en} ngala | \gls 1DU.INCL=OBL up-from mountain SG.PROX=atop be{-nmlz} PL.PROX | \glt `these [people] who live atop the mountains above us’
Content 2: \gsrc sïtik mï kïka tïlwa \textbf{men pen} | \gll sïtik mï kïka tïlwa ma=\textbf{in} \textbf{p-en} | \gls stick 3SG.SUBJ white.ant road 3SG.OBJ=in be{-nmlz} | \glt `the stick that is in the white ant track’

Knowledge Point: Some postpositions seem to function like verbs even without being followed by a \isi{locative verb} form. When such forms occur clause-finally and express the action or event of the \isi{predicate}, they may be considered to be verbs (albeit somewhat \isi{defective} ones). Indeed, they are likely verbs in origin, having begun a process of \isi{grammaticalization}, losing their \isi{verbal morphology} as they come to function more as postpositions. This seems to be the case with the \isi{suppletive} verb ala {\textasciitilde} andï(m/n) ‘see’, both \isi{stem}s of which are used as postpositions with the meaning ‘for’ or ‘from’. However, as \isi{separable verb}s (\sectref{sec:9.2.1}), these forms -- along with the \isi{nominal adjunct} lïmndï ‘eye’ -- convey the verbal meaning ‘see’, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:30}.
Content 1: \gsrc Unan amun lïmndï makape i \textbf{mandïm}. | \gll unan amun lïmndï maka=p-e i ma=\textbf{andï-m} | \gls 1PL.INCL now eye thus=COP-DEP way 3SG.OBJ=see-PFV | \glt `We have now seen this kind of behavior.’

Knowledge Point: Indeed, even when functioning as a verb, ala {\textasciitilde} andï(m/n) ‘see’ generally does not take any \isi{TAM} \isi{suffix}ation \REF{ex:otherwc:31}. It can, however, receive a \isi{dependent marker} \REF{ex:otherwc:32}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nïnji itom mï lïmndï \textbf{nala}. | \gll nï-nji itom mï lïmndï nï=\textbf{ala} | \gls 1SG-POSS father 3SG.SUBJ eye 1SG=see | \glt `My father saw me.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï wa i lïmndï wa \textbf{male}. | \gll ndï wa i lïmndï wa ma=\textbf{ala-e} | \gls 3PL village go.PFV eye village 3SG.OBJ=see-DEP | \glt `They went home and saw the village.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{stem} andï- ‘see’ does, however, permit at least one \isi{TAM} \isi{suffix}, the \isi{irrealis} \isi{suffix} -na ‘\textsc{irr}’, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:33}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ankam moweka ango lïmndï \textbf{mandïna}. | \gll ankam moweka ango lïmndï ma=\textbf{andï-na} | \gls person also NEG eye 3SG.OBJ=see-IRR | \glt `Nor would people see it.’

Knowledge Point: The most frequent \isi{temporal adverb}s are given in \REF{ex:otherwc:34}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:otherwc:35} through \REF{ex:otherwc:41} illustrate some uses of these \isi{temporal adverb}s.
Content 1: \gsrc Una \textbf{amun} mbi. | \gll unan \textbf{amun} mbï-i | \gls 1PL.INCL now here-go.PFV | \glt `We’ve now come here.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Umbe} una angos wombïn ninda? | \gll \textbf{umbe} unan angos wombïn=n ni-nda | \gls tomorrow 1PL.INCL what work=OBL act-IRR | \glt `What [sort of] work will we do tomorrow?’

Knowledge Point: Although the three basic \isi{temporal adverb}s (amun ‘now’, awal ‘yesterday’, and umbe ‘tomorrow’) generally occur immediately after the subject (when it is expressed), they may alternatively occur before the subject (i.e., clause-initially), as in \REF{ex:otherwc:36}, \REF{ex:otherwc:39}, and \REF{ex:otherwc:41}. There is a tendency to place the \isi{temporal adverb} before \isi{postpositional phrase}s, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:42} and \REF{ex:otherwc:43}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Amun} una kalam. | \gll \textbf{amun} unan kalam | \gls now 1PL.INCL knowledge | \glt `Now we know.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Awal} anambi keka we ulwap. | \gll \textbf{awal} an-ambi keka we ulwa=p | \gls yesterday 1PL.EXCL-TOP completely sago nothing=COP | \glt `As for us, we were completely out of sago yesterday.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Umbe} una angos wombïn ninda? | \gll \textbf{umbe} unan angos wombïn=n ni-nda | \gls tomorrow 1PL.INCL what work=OBL act-IRR | \glt `What [sort of] work will we do tomorrow?’
Content 4: \gsrc Nï \textbf{umbe} mol mana. | \gll nï \textbf{umbe} ma=ul ma-na | \gls 1SG tomorrow 3SG.OBJ=with go-IRR | \glt `I would go with her tomorrow.’
Content 5: \gsrc Nï \textbf{amun} wiya may wap. | \gll nï \textbf{amun} u=iya ma=i wap | \gls 1SG now 2SG=toward 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV be.PST | \glt `I went there to you today.’

Knowledge Point: Similarly, \isi{temporal adverb}s tend to precede \isi{oblique}-marked NPs, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:44}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{amun} man ndït. | \gll nï \textbf{amun} ma=n ndï=ta | \gls 1SG now 3SG.OBJ=OBL 3PL=say | \glt ‘I just recently told them.’

Knowledge Point: When \isi{temporal adverb}s occur with other adverbs, however, the order seems rather flexible. In example \REF{ex:otherwc:40}, the \isi{adverb} wolka ‘again’ follows the \isi{temporal adverb} umbe ‘tomorrow’. It is possible, however, for this \isi{adverb} to precede the \isi{temporal adverb} as well. The variability in ordering of adverbs may be seen in \REF{ex:otherwc:45} and \REF{ex:otherwc:46}.
Content 1: \gsrc Una \textbf{umbe} wolka ina. | \gll unan \textbf{umbe} wolka i-na | \gls 1PL.INCL tomorrow again come-IRR | \glt `We’ll come again tomorrow.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngan ango \textbf{amun} \textbf{wolka} maye. | \gll ngan ango \textbf{amun} \textbf{wolka} ma=i-e | \gls 1DU.EXCL NEG now again 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV-DEP | \glt `We have not gone there again lately.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nï ango \textbf{wolka} \textbf{amun} may. | \gll nï ango \textbf{wolka} \textbf{amun} ma=i | \gls 1SG NEG again now 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV | \glt `I have not gone there again lately.’

Knowledge Point: As in example \REF{ex:otherwc:39}, there may also be a preference among some speakers to place the \isi{temporal adverb} before the subject in clauses containing multiple \isi{oblique} expressions, such as adverbs. In example \REF{ex:otherwc:47}, the sentence contains the adverbs amun ‘now’ and wolka ‘again’, the former occurring clause-initially.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Awal} anambi keka we ulwap. | \gll \textbf{awal} an-ambi keka we ulwa=p | \gls yesterday 1PL.EXCL-TOP completely sago nothing=COP | \glt `As for us, we were completely out of sago yesterday.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Amun} yalum ngala wolka mbulop. | \gll \textbf{amun} yalum ngala wolka mbï-u-lo-p | \gls now grandchild PL.PROX again here-from-go-PFV | \glt `Now these grandsons came around here again.’

Knowledge Point: Similarly, \isi{modal adverb}s such as wa ‘just’ may either follow \REF{ex:otherwc:48} or precede \REF{ex:otherwc:49} \isi{temporal adverb}s.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{amun wa} ndale. | \gll ndï \textbf{amun} \textbf{wa} ndï=ale-e | \gls 3PL now just 3PL=scrape-IPFV | \glt `Nowadays they just scrape them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{wa amun} kuli atap. | \gll ndï \textbf{wa} \textbf{amun} kuli ata [na]-p | \gls 3PL just now throw up [DETR]-be | \glt `Now they are just coming up well.’

Knowledge Point: Although one of the defining characteristics of the class of adverbs is that its members do not permit any nominal or \isi{verbal morphology}, this claim is confounded by the fact that words such as amun ‘today’, awal ‘yesterday’, and umbe ‘tomorrow’ may also function as nouns, as illustrated in \REF{ex:otherwc:50} and \REF{ex:otherwc:51}, where the \isi{temporal} words appear to be \isi{head}ing subject NPs.
Content 1: \gsrc Ay ngam \textbf{amun} Prayde. | \gll ay nga-nam \textbf{amun} Prayde | \gls ay SG.PROX{-emph} now Friday | \glt `Ay, that’s it, today is Friday.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Umbe} anmbi angos mundu mï anmapïta u malanda? | \gll \textbf{umbe} an-mbï-i angos mundu mï anma=p-ta u ma=la-nda | \gls tomorrow out-here-go.PFV what food 3SG.SUBJ good=COP-COND 2SG 3SG.OBJ=eat-IRR | \glt `When tomorrow comes what food will be good for you to eat?’

Knowledge Point: These nominal forms may receive the \isi{copular enclitic}. When occurring with the word amun ‘today’, this marker can give the sense of ‘still’ (or, in \isi{negative} \isi{polarity}, ‘yet’), as illustrated by examples \REF{ex:otherwc:52} through \REF{ex:otherwc:56}.
Content 1: \gsrc Unji nungol ngala \textbf{amunpe} kalam ngol mane. | \gll u-nji nungol ngala \textbf{amun=p}-e kalam nga=ul ma-n-e | \gls 2SG-POSS child PL.PROX now=COP-DEP knowledge SG.PROX=with go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `Your children are still in school.’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{amunpe} wol ulwap. | \gll u \textbf{amun=p}-e wol ulwa=p | \gls 2SG now=COP-DEP breast nothing=COP | \glt `You don’t have breasts yet.’

Knowledge Point: When awal ‘yesterday’ is followed by [p], however, it generally has the sense of ‘afternoon’, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:57} and \REF{ex:otherwc:58}. This, rather, seems to be an instantiation of the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be at’, here being \isi{metaphor}ically extended to \isi{temporal} meaning. Something similar seems to occurs with the noun imba ‘night’, in phrases such as imba pe ‘at night’.\footnote{There are no attested uses of umbe ‘tomorrow’ with \isi{copula}r or \isi{locative} marking.}
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Awal pe} inim ndïn apïn up ay ndïnkap. | \gll \textbf{awal} \textbf{p-e} inim ndï=n apïn u-p ay ndï=nïkï-p | \gls afternoon be{-dep} water 3PL=OBL fire put-PFV sago 3PL=dig-PFV | \glt `In the afternoon, [we] put water on the fire and made sago.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mundu anglaluta mawap \textbf{awal pïta}. | \gll mundu angla-lo-ta ma=wap \textbf{awal} \textbf{p-}ta | \gls food await-go-COND 3SG.OBJ=be.PST afternoon be{-cond} | \glt `If [they] were hunting for food, [they] would stay until afternoon.’

Knowledge Point: The other \isi{temporal adverb}s, which never take either nominal or \isi{verbal morphology}, are perhaps better exemplars of adverbs. Like the three adverbs already described, they may appear either before \REF{ex:otherwc:59} or after \REF{ex:otherwc:60} subject NPs.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ipka} ankam ango ulum alepen. | \gll \textbf{ipka} ankam ango ulum ale-p-en | \gls before person NEG palm scrape-PFV-NML | \glt `Before, people didn’t use to scrape sago palms.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{ipka} alan malan upe. | \gll nï \textbf{ipka} ala=n malan u-p-e | \gls 1SG before PL.DIST=OBL hot.water put-PFV-DEP | \glt `I boiled those first.’

Knowledge Point: Whereas ta ‘already’ is clearly monomorphemic, ipka ‘before’ and anganika ‘after’ are each apparently derived from multiple morphemes: the former consisting of the noun ip ‘nose’ and the \isi{postposition} ka ‘at, in, on’, the latter consisting of the noun angani ‘rear’ and the \isi{postposition} ka ‘at, in, on’. While ipka ‘before’ is derived from a crosslinguistically common body-part \isi{metaphor}, \mbox{anganika} ‘after’ (often shortened to [naka]) is not necessarily so, since angani ‘rear’ is not typically used to refer to any part of the human body (cf. mutam ‘back’ and unmbï ‘buttocks’). Sentences \REF{ex:otherwc:61} through \REF{ex:otherwc:64} illustrate the adverbial use of ipka ‘before’ and anganika ‘after’.
Content 1: \gsrc Nïnji inom mï \textbf{ipka} apa mo li. | \gll nï-nji inom mï \textbf{ipka} apa ma=u li-i | \gls 1SG-POSS mother 3SG.SUBJ before house 3SG.OBJ=from down-go.PFV | \glt `My mother went down around the house first.’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{anganika} ndïtana! | \gll u \textbf{anganika} ndï=ta-na | \gls 2SG after 3PL=say-IRR | \glt `Tell them later!’

Knowledge Point: Whereas anganika ‘after’ is viewed here as a single \isi{adverb} (that is, not composed of [angani] and [ka], at least not synchronically) and thus should not accept any \isi{morphological} \isi{inflection}, the \isi{postposition} angani ‘behind’ (as a \isi{postposition}) can indeed have an \isi{object-marker} \isi{clitic}, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:65} and \REF{ex:otherwc:66}.
Content 1: \gsrc Anambi itom \textbf{alangani} i. | \gll an-ambi itom \textbf{ala=angani} i | \gls 1PL.EXCL-TOP father PL.DIST=behind go.PFV | \glt `As for us, we came after [our] fathers.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nïnji aweta nda \textbf{nangani} wonp! | \gll nï-nji aweta anda \textbf{nï=angani} won-p | \gls 1SG-POSS friend SG.DIST 1SG=behind cut-PFV | \glt `That friend of mine has gone behind my back!’

Knowledge Point: More troubling for this analysis of ipka ‘before’ and anganika ‘after’ as adverbs, however, is the occasional use of ipka ‘before’ as a \isi{postposition} as well, as seen in \REF{ex:otherwc:67} and \REF{ex:otherwc:68}.\footnote{It could be, however, that in such instances the postpositional force of ka ‘at, in, on’ is still felt, creating a \isi{postpositional phrase} that means something along the lines of ‘at the nose of’. An additional complication is the clear relationship between the adverbs ipka ‘before’ and anganika ‘after’ and the verbs ip ka- ‘precede’ and angani ka- ‘follow’, respectively (\sectref{sec:9.2.3}). These putative verbs are found in \is{ordinal numeral} ordinal constructions with \isi{nominalizing} \isi{morphology} (\sectref{sec:7.5}).}
Content 1: \gsrc E an tïn alol \textbf{unipka} mbiye! | \gll e an tïn ala=ul \textbf{un=ipka} mbï-i-e | \gls hey 1PL.EXCL dog PL.DIST=with 2PL=before here-go.PFV-DEP | \glt `Hey, we came here with those dogs before you!’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngan \textbf{ndipka} iyen. | \gll ngan \textbf{ndï=ipka} i-en | \gls 1DU.EXCL 3PL=before go.PFV-NMLZ | \glt `We two went ahead of them.’

Knowledge Point: Thus, perhaps ta ‘already’, which permits no verbal \isi{TAM} \isi{suffix}ation, \isi{nominalize}d forms, or \isi{object-marker} \isi{clitic}s, and which is able to occur either before or after the subject, is the most prototypical \isi{temporal adverb} in Ulwa. The use of ta ‘already’ is illustrated in \REF{ex:otherwc:69}, \REF{ex:otherwc:70}, and \REF{ex:otherwc:71}.
Content 1: \gsrc U \textbf{ta} kalampe. | \gll u \textbf{ta} kalam=p-e | \gls 2SG already knowledge=COP-DEP | \glt `You already know.’
Content 2: \gsrc E mï \textbf{ta} keka wapatap. | \gll e mï \textbf{ta} keka wapata=p | \gls hey 3SG.SUBJ already completely dry=COP | \glt `Hey! It’s already completely dry.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Ta} unji anapa ndï u inim nïkape. | \gll \textbf{ta} u-nji anapa ndï u inim nïkï-p-e | \gls already 2SG-POSS sister 3PL 2SG water dig-PFV-DEP | \glt `Already, your sisters have celebrated you.’

Knowledge Point: There is a small set of \isi{locative adverb}s in Ulwa, which are used to indicate position or \isi{direction} \REF{ex:otherwc:72}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The adverbs ata ‘up’ and li ‘down’ may refer either to literal vertical-axis \isi{location}s and \isi{direction}s or to relative \isi{location}s and \isi{direction}s along the river -- that is, ‘upstream’ and ‘downstream’, respectively. In \REF{ex:otherwc:73} and \REF{ex:otherwc:74}, ata ‘up’ and li ‘down’ are being used to refer to vertical-axis \isi{direction}s.
Content 1: \gsrc Ulum maya \textbf{ata} i. | \gll ulum ma=iya \textbf{ata} i | \gls palm 3SG.OBJ=toward up go.PFV | \glt `[It] went up the sago palm.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nungolke ngala kuli \textbf{li} malp. | \gll nungolke ngala kuli \textbf{li} ma=lï-p | \gls child PL.PROX throw down 3SG.OBJ=put-PFV | \glt `These children have thrown [themselves] down there [= the water].’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:otherwc:75} and \REF{ex:otherwc:76}, ata ‘up’ refers to \isi{location}s or \isi{direction}s upstream from a point of reference. In \REF{ex:otherwc:77}, li ‘down’ refers to a \isi{location} or \isi{direction} downstream from the point of reference.
Content 1: \gsrc Wot ngo \textbf{ata} mane. | \gll wot nga=u \textbf{ata} ma-n-e | \gls younger SG.PROX=from up go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `[They] were going upstream from this younger [village].’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï mat \textbf{ata} ndo i. | \gll nï ma=tï \textbf{ata} anda=u i | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=take up SG.DIST=from go.PFV | \glt `I brought it from up there [i.e., from upstream].’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndïmepe ndït \textbf{li} may. | \gll ndï=me-p-e ndï=tï \textbf{li} ma=i | \gls 3PL=sew-PFV-DEP 3PL=take down 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV | \glt `He sewed them and brought them down there [i.e., downstream].’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:otherwc:78} contains both li ‘down’ and ata ‘up’. Here, li ‘down’ occurs within a \isi{relative clause} meaning something like ‘these who stay there downstream’.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Li} mape ngala ngalaya \textbf{ata} mbi. | \gll \textbf{li} ma=p-e ngala ngala=iya \textbf{ata} mbï-i | \gls down 3SG.OBJ=be{-dep} PL.PROX PL.PROX=toward up here-go.PFV | \glt `These people from downstream came upstream here to these people.’

Knowledge Point: Furthermore, upward \isi{motion} and downward \isi{motion} are often \isi{synonymous} in Ulwa with entering and exiting houses, respectively. Since houses are elevated on stilts, one must physically move along the vertical axis in order to enter or exit one. In \REF{ex:otherwc:79}, ata ‘up’ is being used to refer to entering a house. In \REF{ex:otherwc:80} and \REF{ex:otherwc:81}, li ‘down’ connotes exiting a house.
Content 1: \gsrc Mat i \textbf{ata} apa may. | \gll ma=tï i \textbf{ata} apa ma=i | \gls 3SG.OBJ=take go.PFV up house 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV | \glt `[It] brought him up to the house and went with him.’
Content 2: \gsrc Yana mï \textbf{li} membam i atwana mat. | \gll yana mï \textbf{li} ma=imbam i atwana ma=ta | \gls woman 3SG.SUBJ down 3SG.OBJ=under go.PFV question 3SG.OBJ=say | \glt `[His] wife came down under him and asked him a question.’
Content 3: \gsrc Anda ngunaya \textbf{li} nayn. | \gll anda ngunan=iya \textbf{li} na-i-n | \gls SG.DIST 1DU.INCL=toward down DETR-come-PFV | \glt `That one has come down to us [from the house].’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{locative adverb} mbï ‘here’ may be used to indicate \isi{direction} toward the speaker (i.e., ‘hither’) \REF{ex:otherwc:82}.
Content 1: \gsrc Na manji yalum ngala \textbf{mbï} indap. | \gll na ma-nji yalum ngala \textbf{mbï} inda-p | \gls and 3SG.OBJ-POSS grandchild PL.PROX here walk-PFV | \glt `And his grandchildren walked here.’

Knowledge Point: Often, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:82}, the \isi{adverb} mbï ‘here’ occurs as the first member of a \isi{compound verb}. The second member is usually a \isi{motion} verb, such as ma- {\textasciitilde} i- ‘go’, and the \isi{compound} has the sense ‘come (here)’ as seen in \REF{ex:otherwc:83}.
Content 1: \gsrc Na manji yalum ngala \textbf{mbï} indap. | \gll na ma-nji yalum ngala \textbf{mbï} inda-p | \gls and 3SG.OBJ-POSS grandchild PL.PROX here walk-PFV | \glt `And his grandchildren walked here.’
Content 2: \gsrc Atuma numan anda mï \textbf{mbi}. | \gll Atuma numan anda mï \textbf{mbï-i} | \gls [name] husband SG.DIST 3SG.SUBJ here-go.PFV | \glt `Atuma’s husband -- he came.’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Compound}s formed with mbï ‘here’ and other verbs are possible as well, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:85}, where the \isi{compound} is headed by the verb lï- ‘put’. In the verb in this example, the \isi{adverb} mbï ‘here’ combines with an ‘out’, which is not known to occur independently as an \isi{adverb}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï ndït \textbf{anmbïlïp} ndïmoke amblanane. | \gll ndï ndï=tï \textbf{an-mbï-lï-p} ndï=moko-e ambla-na-n-e | \gls 3PL 3PL=take out-here-put-PFV 3PL=take-DEP PL.REFL=give-PFV-DEP | \glt `They got them out and shared them among themselves.’

Knowledge Point: With \isi{motion} verbs such as ma- {\textasciitilde} i- ‘go’, \isi{compound}s containing the components an ‘out’ and mbï ‘here’ give the sense of going outside or coming outside (from being within a house, jungle region, etc.), as in \REF{ex:otherwc:86} and \REF{ex:otherwc:87}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï wolka \textbf{anmbi}. | \gll ndï wolka \textbf{an-mbï-i} | \gls 3PL again out-here-go.PFV | \glt `They went out again.’
Content 2: \gsrc Wolka maya \textbf{anmbi} mol natana. | \gll wolka ma=iya \textbf{an-mbï-i} ma=ul na-ta-na | \gls again 3SG.OBJ=toward out-here-go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=with DETR-say-IRR | \glt `Having come out to him, [we] will talk with him again.’

Knowledge Point: To indicate \isi{direction} away from the speaker (i.e., ‘hence’), the \isi{adverb} mbï ‘here’ may be combined with the \isi{postposition} u ‘from, in, at, around, along’ \REF{ex:otherwc:88}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ngo Ganmalin u \textbf{mbu} matïn mana. | \gll nga=u Ganmali=n u \textbf{mbï-u} ma=tï-n ma-na | \gls SG.PROX=from [name]=OBL from here-from 3SG.OBJ=take-PFV go-IRR | \glt `From this [place], having gotten it from here, from Ganmali, [they] will go.’

Knowledge Point: The same \isi{compound} mbu ‘from here, hence’ (< mbï-u) can have not only \isi{ablative}, but also \isi{locative} sense (i.e., ‘[at] here’ in addition to ‘from here’), as in \REF{ex:otherwc:89} and \REF{ex:otherwc:90}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndïn \textbf{mbu} inum awe. | \gll ndï=n \textbf{mbï-u} inum aw-e | \gls 3PL=OBL here-from ground put.IPFV-DEP | \glt `[They] bury them here.’
Content 2: \gsrc Una we apa \textbf{mbu} ulwap. | \gll unan we apa \textbf{mbï-u} ulwa=p | \gls 1PL.INCL sago house here-from nothing=COP | \glt `We don’t have any sago here at home.’

Knowledge Point: Especially when occurring with the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be at’, mbï ‘here’ can serve more of a nominal function -- that is, ‘here’ in the sense of ‘this place’ \REF{ex:otherwc:91}.
Content 1: \gsrc Owet yena ngusuwa anda \textbf{mbïpe}. | \gll Owet yena ngusuwa anda \textbf{mbï-p}-e | \gls [name] woman poor SG.DIST here-be{-ipfv} | \glt `Owet’s wife, the poor thing, was here.’

Knowledge Point: Like other \isi{deictic} words, mbï ‘here’ can also be used by speakers to project a \isi{deictic center} to a point other than the ego (\sectref{sec:7.3}), as in \REF{ex:otherwc:92}, where it is translated in \ili{English} as ‘there’.
Content 1: \gsrc Alum mokotïp an mol \textbf{mbïwap}. | \gll alum ma=kot-p an ma=ul \textbf{mbï-wap} | \gls child 3SG.OBJ=break-PFV 1PL.EXCL 3SG.OBJ=with here-be.PST | \glt `She bore a child, and we were there with her.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{locative} word ando ‘there, thence’ is a \isi{compound}, composed of the \isi{deictic} word anda ‘that’ and the \isi{postposition} u ‘from, in, at, around, along’. Examples \REF{ex:otherwc:93}, \REF{ex:otherwc:94}, and \REF{ex:otherwc:95} illustrate its use. See also example \REF{ex:det:153} in \sectref{sec:7.3} and example \REF{ex:pred:1} in \sectref{sec:10.1}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ando} una mape. | \gll \textbf{anda=u} unan ma=p-e | \gls SG.DIST=from 1PL.INCL 3SG.OBJ=be{-ipfv} | \glt `We are there.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nga nganji pul \textbf{ando}. | \gll nga nga-nji pul \textbf{anda=u} | \gls SG.PROX SG.PROX-POSS piece SG.DIST=from | \glt `This is this one’s piece [of the river] over there.’
Content 3: \gsrc Tïlwa mï \textbf{ando} i. | \gll tïlwa mï \textbf{anda=u} i | \gls road 3SG.SUBJ SG.DIST=from go.PFV | \glt `The track went from there.’
Content 4: \gsrc \textbf{Ala} ta ando apïn tï lïp. | \gll \textbf{ala} ta anda=u apïn tï lï-p | \gls PL.DIST already SG.DIST=from fire take put-PFV | \glt `People have already set fire there.’
Content 5: \gsrc Tumbuna la mbïpe \textbf{Wopata pe} ala ando. | \gll tumbuna ala mbï-p-e \textbf{Wopata} \textbf{p-e} ala anda=u | \gls grandparent PL.DIST here-be-DEP [place] be-DEP PL.DIST SG.DIST=from | \glt `When the grandparents were here at Wopata they [went] from there.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{locative} words nu ‘near’, ngaya ‘far’, and wala ‘far, far-off’ generally function as \isi{adjective}s (\sectref{sec:5.4}), but they do contain some curious distributional properties, such as variable \isi{word order} with respect to other constituents. This makes them seem somewhat adverb-like. Moreover, since their etymologies seem to reflect origins as \isi{postpositional phrase}s, it should not be surprising that they behave more like \isi{oblique}s than like prototypical \isi{adjective}s (\sectref{sec:11.4}). I propose \mbox{etymologies} for these three words in \REF{ex:otherwc:96}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:otherwc:97}, nu ‘near’ is modifying a verb -- that is, it is functioning as an \isi{adverb}.
Content 1: \gsrc Iwïl nga \textbf{nu} kukawe. | \gll iwïl nga \textbf{nu} kuk-aw-e | \gls moon SG.PROX near gather-put.IPFV-DEP | \glt `[The end of] this month is drawing near.’

Knowledge Point: Likewise, \REF{ex:otherwc:98} illustrates the adverbial use of ngaya ‘far’, which can also be seen in example \REF{ex:syntax:43} in \sectref{sec:13.1.2} and example \REF{ex:syntax:110} in \sectref{sec:13.2.4}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï ndul \textbf{ngaya} mana awlop. | \gll nï ndï=ul \textbf{ngaya} ma-na awlop | \gls 1SG 3PL=with far go-IRR in.vain | \glt `I want to go far with them but can’t.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ankam mï \textbf{ngaya} i. | \gll ankam mï \textbf{ngaya} i | \gls person 3SG.SUBJ far go.PFV | \glt `The person went far away.’
Content 3: \gsrc Tarambi \textbf{wana} apka nïklop ma ngaya \textbf{manat}! | \gll Tarambi \textbf{wana} apka nï=klop ma ngaya ma-na-\textbf{t} | \gls [name] PROH very 1SG=cross go far go-IRR-SPEC | \glt `Tarambi, don’t go completely bypass me and go far away!’

Knowledge Point: Adverbs of manner modify sentences by providing additional information on the way in which an event occurs or a state exists. Although this information is often conveyed through other means (e.g., \isi{adjective}s, \isi{postpositional phrase}s, or even whole clauses), there is a small set of manner adverbs, the most frequent of which are given in \REF{ex:otherwc:99}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: One readily apparent formal trait shared by all these words is their ending in [ka], which, in these words, is taken to be a formative meaning something like ‘thus, in this manner, in that manner’.\footnote{The form luke ‘also, too’ may derive from ul {\textasciitilde} lu ‘with’ + ka ‘thus’ + \textit{{}-e} ‘\textsc{dep}’ -- that is, the form [ka] is probably present in this \isi{adverb} as well, at least diachronically.} These adverbs of manner seem much less amenable to pre-subject position than the \isi{temporal adverb}s are, and their inclusion within the larger class of adverbs is, admittedly, largely based on \isi{semantic} grounds. Sentences \REF{ex:otherwc:100} through \REF{ex:otherwc:112} illustrate their use.
Content 1: \gsrc Woni mï \textbf{apka} wutota. | \gll Woni mï \textbf{apka} wutota | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ very tall | \glt `Woni is very tall.’
Content 2: \gsrc Inom ndï \textbf{moweka} ango unan tïngïn inap. | \gll inom ndï \textbf{moweka} ango unan tïngïn ina-p | \gls mother 3PL also NEG 1PL.INCL many get-PFV | \glt `And another thing: [our] mothers didn’t have many of us.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{adverb} luke ‘also, too’ can be found in examples \REF{ex:verbs:45} in \sectref{sec:4.8}, \REF{ex:verbs:60} in \sectref{sec:4.9}, \REF{ex:otherwc:7} in \sectref{sec:8.1}, \REF{ex:complex:1} in \sectref{sec:12.1.1}, \REF{ex:complex:96} in \sectref{sec:12.3}, and \REF{ex:syntax:175} in \sectref{sec:13.3.4}.
Content 1: \gsrc Asika lïmndï \textbf{ndïlpïpe} ngala luke asi tï nap ndala une. | \gll asi-ka lïmndï ndï=lï-\textbf{p-ïp}-e ngala luke asi tï na-p ndï=ala uni-e | \gls sit-let eye 3PL=put-PFV-PFV-DEP PL.PROX too sit take DETR-be 3PL=for shout-IPFV | \glt `After [they] had sat and watched them, these people also took seats, cheering them on.’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gsrc An luke \textbf{unangani} ata i. | \gll an luke un=\textbf{angani} ata i | \gls 1PL.EXCL too 3PL=behind up go.PFV | \glt `We, too, came up behind you.’
Content 4: \gsrc \textbf{Dimes Susan min} luke i mapta minji itana mane. | \gll \textbf{Dimes} \textbf{Susan} \textbf{min} luke i ma=p-ta min-nji ita-na ma-n-e | \gls [name] [name] 3DU too go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} 3DU-POSS build-IRR go{-ipfv-dep} | \glt `If Dimes and Susan go there, too, [then they] are going to build their [house there].’
Content 5: \gsrc Apa mbïpe itom inom min luke nji ulwap. | \gll {[apa} {mbï-p-e]} itom inom min luke nji ulwa=p | \gls {[house} here-be{-dep]} father mother 3DU too thing nothing=COP | \glt `The two home-owners have nothing either.’
Content 6: \gsrc A un \textbf{wana} apa mapta luke natana! | \gll a un \textbf{wana} apa ma=p-ta luke na-ta-na | \gls INTERJ 2PL PROH house 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} too DETR-say-IRR | \glt `Hey, if you’re in the house, don’t talk either!’

Knowledge Point: In addition to these, there is another \isi{adverb} of manner, one which seems to be permitted only in \isi{negative} \isi{polarity}, and which is in some ways the \isi{negative} counterpart to wolka ‘again’. This \isi{adverb}, tïki ‘(ever) again, anymore, else’, may be seen in \isi{negative} sentences, such as \REF{ex:otherwc:113} and \REF{ex:otherwc:114}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{ango} \textbf{tïki} itom luwa ndule. | \gll ndï \textbf{ango} \textbf{tïki} itom luwa ndï=u-lo-e | \gls 3PL NEG again father place 3PL=from-go-IPFV | \glt `They don’t go around in [their] father’s places anymore.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{ango} \textbf{tïki} ikali usina. | \gll nï \textbf{ango} \textbf{tïki} i-kali u=si-na | \gls 1SG NEG again hand-send 2SG=push-IRR | \glt `I won’t hold you again.’

Knowledge Point: Notably, tïki ‘(ever) again, anymore, else’ is permitted in \isi{question}s as well, which, at least historically, seem to have derived from clauses of \isi{negative} \isi{polarity} (\sectref{sec:13.1.2}). Questions \REF{ex:otherwc:115} and \REF{ex:otherwc:116} both contain tïki ‘(ever) again, anymore, else’.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} luwa \textbf{tïki} ko nji kuma ndïtïna? | \gll \textbf{ango} luwa \textbf{tïki} ko nji kuma ndï=tï-na | \gls which place more just thing some 3PL=take-IRR | \glt `Where else could [we] get some things?’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Tïki} unan \textbf{angos} natana? | \gll \textbf{tïki} unan \textbf{angos} na-ta-na | \gls again 1PL.INCL what DETR-say-IRR | \glt `What else should we say?’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{adverb} maka ‘thus’, unlike most other adverbs, somewhat commonly occurs with the \isi{copular enclitic} =p ‘\textsc{cop}’. The effectively \isi{verbalized} form [makap] has the meaning ‘be like’, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:117}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kalim mï \textbf{makap}. | \gll kalim mï \textbf{maka=p} | \gls cassowary 3SG.SUBJ thus=COP | \glt `The cassowary is like that.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:otherwc:118}, the form [makap] ‘be like’ is further marked with the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’.
Content 1: \gsrc Amun una keka \textbf{makape}. | \gll amun unan keka \textbf{maka=p-e} | \gls now 1PL.INCL completely thus=COP-DEP | \glt `But nowadays we are completely like this.’

Knowledge Point: This \isi{verbalized} form of maka ‘thus’ can even, in turn, be \isi{nominalize}d, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:119}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Makapen} mï nay. | \gll \textbf{maka=p-en} mï na-i | \gls thus=COP-NMLZ 3SG.SUBJ DETR-go.PFV | \glt `That way has gone.’

Knowledge Point: This \isi{verbalized} form of maka ‘thus’ is often used in \isi{relative clause}s (\sectref{sec:12.3}), as in \REF{ex:otherwc:120} and \REF{ex:otherwc:121}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yetani lan u \textbf{makape} ambet matïn. | \gll Yetani ala=n u [\textbf{maka=p-e}] ambet ma=tï-n | \gls Yamen PL.DIST=OBL from [thus=COP-DEP] magic 3SG.OBJ=take-PFV | \glt `[They] got magic like this from the Yamen people.’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{makape} nji ulwata u awlop! | \gll u [\textbf{maka-p-e} nji] ulwa-ta u awlop | \gls 2SG [thus=COP-DEP thing] nothing-COND 2SG in.vain | \glt `If you don’t have things like this, you’re lost!’

Knowledge Point: Often the \isi{embedded clause} formed with [makape] has a similar grammatical function to the plain \isi{adverb} maka ‘thus’ \REF{ex:otherwc:122}.
Content 1: \gsrc Un \textbf{makape} imba wombam niya ita … | \gll un [\textbf{maka=p-e}] imba wombam nï=iya i-ta | \gls 2PL [thus=COP-DEP] night middle 1SG=toward go.PFV-COND | \glt `If you come to me like this in the middle of the night …’

Knowledge Point: In addition to its use as an \isi{adverb}, maka ‘thus’ is very frequently used as a filler word (cf. \ili{Tok Pisin} olsem ‘thus’, \ili{German} also ‘thus’, etc.). When used as such, it is generally translated as ‘like’, following contemporary \ili{English} \isi{idiom} \REF{ex:otherwc:123}. As a filler word, maka ‘thus’ can occur in any position in a sentence, even within NPs, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:124}.
Content 1: \gsrc Wusimali \textbf{maka} in tï Kayta nane. | \gll Wusimali \textbf{maka} in tï Kayta na-n-e | \gls [name] thus get take [name] give-PFV-DEP | \glt `Wusimali, like, bought [an axe] and gave [it] to Kayta.’
Content 2: \gsrc Anji \textbf{maka} ngata ndï ndul iyen. | \gll an-nji \textbf{maka} ngata ndï ndï=ul i-en | \gls 1PL.EXCL-POSS thus grand 3PL 3PL=with go.PFV-NMLZ | \glt `Our, like, ancestors were the ones who went with them.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{adverb} tap ‘maybe’ is used to show the possibility of an event’s occurrence, whether \isi{present}, \isi{past}, or \isi{future}. Fittingly, since its use signals speculation on the part of the speaker, it often accompanies a verb with the \isi{speculative} \isi{suffix} -t ‘\textsc{spec}’ (\sectref{sec:4.11}). Like other adverbs, it often occurs immediately after the subject, when expressed. It tends to precede \isi{temporal adverb}s, when these occur in the same clause. It does not permit any form of \isi{inflection}. Sentences \REF{ex:otherwc:125}, \REF{ex:otherwc:126}, and \REF{ex:otherwc:127} illustrate the use of the \isi{epistemic adverb} tap ‘maybe’.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{tap} amun ina. | \gll mï \textbf{tap} amun i-na | \gls 3SG.SUBJ maybe now come-IRR | \glt `He might come today.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Tap} umbe Kumba mana. | \gll \textbf{tap} umbe Kumba ma-na | \gls maybe tomorrow Bun go-IRR | \glt `Maybe tomorrow [I] will go to Bun [village].’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Tap} manji yawa ngawl i. | \gll \textbf{tap} ma-nji yawa nga=ul i | \gls maybe 3SG.OBJ-POSS uncle SG.PROX=with go.PFV | \glt `[He] might have gone with [his] uncle.’

Knowledge Point: The most frequent discourse adverbs are given in \REF{ex:otherwc:128}. It is notoriously difficult to provide accurate translations of words that serve modal or discourse functions. The glosses provided here represent my best approximation of their meaning and function.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The \isi{adverb} kop ‘please’ is often used to soften \isi{command}s -- that is, to make \isi{polite} \isi{request}s \REF{ex:otherwc:129}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kop} nambï wiwila lakana! | \gll \textbf{kop} nambï wiwila la-ka-na | \gls please skin light IRR-let-IRR | \glt `Let [your] body [become] light!’

Knowledge Point: More examples and details relating to this use of kop ‘please’ may be found in the section on \isi{command}s and \isi{request}s (\sectref{sec:13.2.2}). As an \isi{adverb}, kop ‘please’ can also be used in statements. Here it can convey a sense of care or patience \REF{ex:otherwc:130}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{kop} lïmndï anul pe. | \gll mï \textbf{kop} lïmndï an=ul p-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ please eye 1PL.EXCL=with be{-ipfv} | \glt `She stays with us, watching [us] patiently.’

Knowledge Point: Three forms that are frequently used in discourse are kwa {\textasciitilde} ko {\textasciitilde} wa ‘just’, the first of which is identical to the \isi{numeral} kwa ‘one’, and the second of which is clearly derived from the first.\footnote{The form wa ‘just’ may also be related to kwa ‘one’, although its derivation is less clear.} All three forms share essentially the same set of functions. Often translated as ‘just’, they add a degree of casualness to a statement. Sometimes they convey a sense of ‘simply’, other times a mildly \isi{negative} sense of ‘without care’ or ‘without reason’. Very often, however, it is hard for me to ascribe any clear meaning to them (at least in the \ili{English} translation). These three forms -- kwa {\textasciitilde} ko {\textasciitilde} wa ‘just’ -- are illustrated by examples \REF{ex:otherwc:131}, \REF{ex:otherwc:132}, and \REF{ex:otherwc:133}, respectively.
Content 1: \gsrc Ay nï \textbf{kwa} apa mbïpe mane? | \gll ay nï \textbf{kwa} apa mbï-p-e ma-n-e | \gls ay 1SG just house here-be-DEP go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `Ay, am I just going to stay here?’
Content 2: \gsrc Lamndu \textbf{ko} minamap. | \gll lamndu \textbf{ko} min=ama-p | \gls pig just 3DU=eat-PFV | \glt `A pig ate them.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Wa} inde le. | \gll \textbf{wa} inda-e lo-e | \gls just walk-DEP go-IPFV | \glt `[We] would just walk around.’

Knowledge Point: Serving the same function as kwa {\textasciitilde} ko {\textasciitilde} wa ‘just’ is the \isi{adverb} lolop ‘just’, which has been \isi{borrow}ed from the neighboring language \ili{Ap Ma}. It often occurs immediately following wa ‘just’, but may occur independently as well. In examples \REF{ex:otherwc:134}, \REF{ex:otherwc:135}, and \REF{ex:otherwc:136}, it has a \isi{frustrative} sense.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï wa \textbf{lolop} i mangusuwa nji molop lïp. | \gll nï wa \textbf{lolop} i ma-ngusuwa nji ma=lo-p lï-p | \gls 1SG just just go.PFV 3SG.OBJ-poor thing 3SG.OBJ=cut-PFV put-PFV | \glt `Frustratedly, I just went and cut the poor thing’s thing [= sago palm jungle].’
Content 2: \gsrc Una wa \textbf{lolop} wa pe. | \gll unan wa \textbf{lolop} wa p-e | \gls 1PL.EXCL just just village be-IPFV | \glt `We are just [hanging around] in the village.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nambi tembi nape nï wa \textbf{lolop} indana. | \gll nï-ambi tembi na-p-e nï wa \textbf{lolop} inda-na | \gls 1SG-TOP bad DETR-be-DEP 1SG just just walk-IRR | \glt `As for me, I’m becoming unfit, so I’ll just go around [without worrying about other people].’

Knowledge Point: Similar in function to kwa {\textasciitilde} ko {\textasciitilde} wa ‘just’ and lolop ‘just’ is the word woyambïn ‘pointlessly, fruitlessly’, which has a much more \isi{negative} connotation. This word looks very much like it has derived from other words, in part because of the unusual \isi{diphthong} [oy] (\sectref{sec:2.1.7}). It may derive from /wa-i-ambï=n/ ‘just-go.\textsc{pfv-sg.refl=obl’} -- that is, a \isi{phrase} having meant something like ‘just went with himself/herself/itself’. This is only speculative. Examples \REF{ex:otherwc:137} and \REF{ex:otherwc:138} illustrate the use of woyambïn ‘pointlessly, fruitlessly’.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{woyambïn} ndul ndïnanape. | \gll nï \textbf{woyambïn} ndï=ul ndï=na-na-p-e | \gls 1SG pointlessly 3PL=with 3PL=DETR-feed-PFV-DEP | \glt `I fed them along with them [= my biological children] for nothing.’
Content 2: \gsrc Na \textbf{woyambïn} matane. | \gll na \textbf{woyambïn} ma=ta-n-e | \gls and pointlessly 3SG.OBJ=say-IPFV-DEP | \glt `But [we] are just wasting time talking about it.’

Knowledge Point: Some of the adverbs described in \sectref{sec:8.2.3} also seem to behave at times much like \isi{modal} or discourse adverbs, carrying subtle connotations or serving various discourse functions. The \isi{adverb} wolka ‘again, in turn’ may be used in narratives to tie together events in series, especially when they are somewhat repetitive. It may thus often be translated with the \ili{English} expression ‘and then …’. In \REF{ex:otherwc:139}, the narrator recounts a narrative of people traveling frome one place to another, using wolka ‘again, in turn’ as a linking element.
Content 1: \gsrc Biwat inim menklop i atay. Ataye \textbf{wolka} ngo nay. \textbf{Wolka} ngo anji wandam ngayte i. | \gll Biwat inim ma=in-klop i ata-i ata-i-e \textbf{wolka} nga=u na-i \textbf{wolka} nga=u an-nji wandam nga=ita-e i | \gls [place] water 3SG.OBJ=in-cross go.PFV up-go.PFV up-go.PFV-DEP again SG.PROX=from DETR-go.PFV again SG.PROX=from 1PL.EXCL-POSS jungle SG.PROX=build-DEP go.PFV | \glt `[They] went following the Biwat river, went up. Having gone up, [they] came this way. And then from here, [they] came and built our jungle [area].’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{adverb} maweka {\textasciitilde} moweka ‘also, moreover’ also seems at times to serve \isi{modal} functions. Its usage here seems parallel to \isi{modal} uses of \ili{Tok Pisin} tu ‘also, too’, and it is possibly a \isi{calque} of that word (cf. similar phenomena in \chapref{sec:15}). It can be used to add a degree of incredulity, to strengthen a \isi{request} for confirmation in a \isi{question}, or to add a sense of wonder to a statement. Its use is illustrated by examples \REF{ex:otherwc:140} and \REF{ex:otherwc:141}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nambi \textbf{maweka} nïnji ala wala luwa ndap. | \gll nï-ambi \textbf{maweka} nï-nji ala wala luwa anda=p | \gls 1SG-TOP also 1SG-POSS PL.DIST far.off place SG.DIST=be | \glt `As for me, those [relatives] of mine are in a far-off place.’
Content 2: \gsrc Kanangula \textbf{moweka} ango wa mbïwap. | \gll Kanangula \textbf{moweka} ango wa mbï-wap | \gls [name] also NEG village here-be.PST | \glt `Kanangula did not [even bother to] stay in the village.’

Knowledge Point: It has already been shown how the \isi{adverb} maka ‘thus’ can also function as a filler word (\sectref{sec:8.2.3}). In a somewhat similar fashion, the \isi{placeholder word} \linebreak mïngamata ‘whatchamacallit’ can be used when a speaker is trying to retrieve a word, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:142} and \REF{ex:otherwc:143}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kolpe manji \textbf{mïngamata} wonmi ndïwonpop. | \gll Kolpe ma-nji \textbf{mïngamata} wonmi ndï=won-p-op | \gls [name] 3SG.OBJ-POSS whatchamacallit hair 3PL=cut-PFV-PFV | \glt `Kolpe had cut his -- what’s it? -- hair.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: First, it is possible to use \isi{dependent clause}s to express adverbial notions. Such clauses typically contain \isi{verbalized} forms of \isi{adjective}s or nouns that express properties \REF{ex:otherwc:144}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Andïlpe} ndïmisisinap. | \gll \textbf{andïl=p-e} ndï=misisina-p | \gls careful=COP-DEP 3PL=arrange-PFV | \glt `[They] carefully arranged them.’

Knowledge Point: Additionally, adverb-like notions can be expressed with \isi{postpositional phrase}s or \isi{oblique}-marked NPs; these usages are often \isi{metaphor}ical, as in \REF{ex:otherwc:145} and \REF{ex:otherwc:146}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nambli lu} manen. | \gll \textbf{nambli} \textbf{lu} ma-n-en | \gls feather with go-IPFV-NMLZ | \glt `[The water] is going quickly.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Apïnï} mowonlïp. | \gll \textbf{apïn=nï} ma=won-lï-p | \gls fire=OBL 3SG.OBJ=cut-put-PFV | \glt `[He] cut it down quickly.’

Knowledge Point: There is in Ulwa a small set of negators, words that indicate that the \isi{polarity} of a sentence is \isi{negative} as opposed to \isi{positive}, which is taken to be the unspecified, default \isi{polarity}. The basic \isi{negative} marker used in \isi{verbal negation} is ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ (\sectref{sec:13.3.1}). To express \isi{non-verbal negation}, one of two clause-final negators is often used, sometimes co-occurring with ango ‘\textsc{neg}’. These are me ‘\textsc{neg’} and kom {\textasciitilde} kome ‘\textsc{neg}’ (\sectref{sec:13.3.2}). In \isi{negative command}s, the prohibitive marker wana {\textasciitilde} wanap ‘\textsc{proh’} is used (\sectref{sec:13.3.3}). The \isi{interjection} ase ‘no’ is used to respond \isi{negative}ly to \isi{question}s (\sectref{sec:8.3.3}, \sectref{sec:13.3.5}). The negators are summarized in \REF{ex:otherwc:147}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: There is also in Ulwa a small set of \isi{interrogative word}s, which are used in wh- questions (i.e., \isi{content question}s). Their forms and functions are described more fully in \sectref{sec:13.1}, but they may be presented together here in terms of their \isi{word class} membership. They are all functionally similar in that they help form \isi{interrogative} sentences. However, they are likely not a \isi{morphosyntactic}ally distinct class, but rather a group composed of different grammatical categories. These \isi{interrogative word}s are given in \REF{ex:otherwc:148}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Finally, there are in Ulwa a number of \isi{interjection}s, usually short words used to express a variety of thoughts or emotions. The words equivalent to ‘yes’, ‘no’, and ‘OK’ are considered here as well. In the list of \isi{interjection}s given in \REF{ex:otherwc:149}, the exclamation point (!) indicates emphatic pronunciation, the question mark (?) indicates rising \isi{intonation}, and the triangular colon (ː) indicates extended \is{vowel length} \isi{vowel} \isi{length}. Note also that the \isi{interjection} mm ‘uh-uh’ is pronounced as two \isi{syllabic nasal}s separated by a \is{glottal stop} \isi{glottal} \isi{stop} (i.e., [mʔm]).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In this grammar, \isi{interjection}s are sometimes glossed with translations like those in \REF{ex:otherwc:149}, and at other times they are glossed with the abbreviation ‘\textsc{interj}’, depending on what is clearer. The two forms on this list that deserve the most comment are =o ‘\textsc{voc}’ and mawnam ‘that’s it’, the former since it seems limited to use as an \isi{enclitic}, and the latter because it seems to be polymorphemic, at least historically.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The \isi{interjection} =o ‘\textsc{voc}’ is possibly a \isi{loan} from \ili{Tok Pisin}.\footnote{Ulwa has no native words that begin with \isi{mid vowel}s /e/ or /o/. If not a \isi{loan} from \ili{Tok Pisin}, then the form [=o] may at least be influenced by \ili{Tok Pisin} pronunciation. This \isi{vocative} \isi{interjection} has an \isi{allomorph} =wo ‘\textsc{voc}’, which may represent an indigenous \isi{interjection}.} Examples \REF{ex:otherwc:150} through \REF{ex:otherwc:154} illustrate the use of =o ‘\textsc{voc’}, both as an \isi{interjection} of emphasis and as a \isi{vocative} form used when calling to people.
Content 1: \gsrc Mawanat \textbf{Supamo}! | \gll ma=wana-ta Supam=\textbf{o} | \gls 3SG.OBJ=feel-say [name]=VOC | \glt `[They] called to her: “Supam!”’
Content 2: \gsrc Alanji amba \textbf{ndo}! | \gll ala-nji amba anda=\textbf{o} | \gls PL.DIST{-poss} mens.house SG.DIST{=voc} | \glt `Over there they have magic!’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{interjection} mawnam ‘that’s it’ is used to signal the \isi{emphatic} identification of a referent or to show approval of a thought or action.\footnote{Cf. \ili{Tok Pisin} em nau ‘it now’, used as an \isi{interjection} to mean ‘that’s it’.} The word may contain the word maw ‘correct’, although I consider it also possible that this shorter word is itself a \isi{backformation} from mawnam ‘that’s it’. The [-nam] ending suggests a pronominal origin of this word (cf. the \isi{emphatic} \isi{suffix} -nam ‘\textsc{emph}’, \sectref{sec:6.7}). Perhaps it is an elaboration of the form mï-nam ‘3\textsc{sg.subj}-\textsc{emph}’. The form mawnam ‘that’s it’ may take the ending [-e]. It is unclear whether this is the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’ (\sectref{sec:12.2.1}) or simply a further \isi{emphatic} \isi{syllable}. Sentences \REF{ex:otherwc:155} through \REF{ex:otherwc:158} exemplify the use of mawnam ‘that’s it’.
Content 1: \gsrc Makape i \textbf{mawnam}. | \gll maka=p-e i \textbf{mawnam} | \gls thus=COP-DEP way thats.it | \glt `Behavior like that -- that’s it.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Mawname}. | \gll mawnam-e | \gls thats.it-DEP? | \glt `That’s right.’
